Graphical abstracts This review unravels the grievances between LMA, LiNO3 and carbonate electrolytes, and enables a comprehensive analysis of LMA stabilizing mechanism with LiNO3, dissolution principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes, and LiNO3 introduction strategies. This review converges attention on a point that the LiNO3-introduction into commercial carbonate electrolytes is an imperious choice to realize practical LMBs with commercial 4 V layered cathode. Li-metal batteries (LMBs) regain research prominence owing to the ever-increasing high-energy requirements. Commercially available carbonate electrolytes exhibit unfavourable parasitic reactions with Li-metal anode (LMA), leading to the formation of unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and the breed of Li dendrites/dead Li. Significantly, lithium nitrate (LiNO3), an excellent film-forming additive, proves crucial to construct a robust Li3N/Li2O/Li x NO y -rich SEI after combining with ether-based electrolytes. Thus, the given challenge leads to natural ideas which suggest the incorporation of LiNO3 into commercial carbonate for practical LMBs. Regrettably, LiNO3 demonstrates limited solubility (∼800 ppm) in commercial carbonate electrolytes. Thence, developing stable SEI and dendrite-free LMA with the incorporation of LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes is an efficacious strategy to realize robust LMBs via a scalable and cost-effective route. Therefore, this review unravels the grievances between LMA, LiNO3 and carbonate electrolytes, and enables a comprehensive analysis of LMA stabilizing mechanism with LiNO3, dissolution principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes, and LiNO3 introduction strategies. This review converges attention on a point that the LiNO3-introduction into commercial carbonate electrolytes is an imperious choice to realize practical LMBs with commercial 4 V layered cathode. Keywords Li-metal battery Carbonate electrolyte Lithium nitrate Stabilization mechanism Dissolution principle Introduction strategy 1 Introduction and scope Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have gradually dominated the market of portable and consumer electronics owing to competitive commercial advantages over the past 25 years. Unfortunately, in facing the upcoming boom in electric vehicles (EVs), mileage anxiety appears progressively because even the state-of-the-art intercalation-dominated LIBs deliver insufficient specific energy (below 300 Wh kg−1 at the cell level), inaccessible to meet the ever-increasing energy density requirements of electric automotives and achieve the dual-carbon goal [1–3]. Therefore, conversion-based Li-metal batteries (LMBs) have regained tremendous research interest in recent five years. Compared with the upper capacity limitation of graphite anode (372 mA h g−1, calculated as LiC6), Li-metal anode (LMA) exhibits high-energy competitive features including 10-time-graphite theoretical capacity (3860 mA h g−1), low electrochemical potential (−3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode), and extra-low theoretical density (0.534 g cm−3), considered as the “holy grail” and an imperious candidate for the next-generation battery technology [4–7]. 1.1 Practical Li-metal batteries The gravimetric energy density of a Li-metal full cell depends on the specific capacity and voltage window of the anode and cathode, as depicted by Eq. (1) [8]. (1) E = C c × C a C c + C a × V c - V a Where E represents the energy density, C c/C a and V c/V a represent the specific capacity and potential window of the cathode/anode in Eq. (1), respectively. Lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries based on the bidirectional cathode/anode conversion reaction exhibit promising gravimetric energy density of ∼900 Wh kg−1 and ∼600 Wh kg−1, respectively, due to the ultrahigh specific capacity of O2 cathode and S cathode (1672 mA h g−1) in addition to the advantages of employing LMA [9–12]. However, the intercalation-type cathodes are still the most promising cathodes for practical LMBs, including low-voltage Li4Ti5O12 (LTO), 3-V-class LiFePO4 (LFP) cathodes, 4-V-class LiCoO2 (LCO), LiNi x Co y Mn/Al z O2 (x + y + z = 1) (NCM/NCA), Li-rich Mn-based cathodes, 5-V-class LiCoPO4, and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathodes [13–19]. Among these cathodes, Li-LTO batteries and Li-LFP batteries fail to exhibit significant energy density improvement toward current Li-based batteries due to the capacity/voltage limitations of cathodes. The 5 V LMBs are subject to the suitable electrolyte for ultrahigh-voltage cathode, and 4 V LMBs effectively achieve higher specific energy while in line with market practicality by replacing graphite with metallic Li [20,21]. When incorporating advanced 4-V-class cathodes, dreamy 500 Wh kg−1 (a new goal set in automotive field) specific-energy LMBs can be realized, which suggests a fossil-fueled-cars-matched ∼800 km driving range on a single charge for an electric vehicle (EV) [8,22]. 1.2 Liquid electrolyte for practical Li-metal batteries In a practical 4 V Li-metal full cell, the rational design of liquid electrolyte needs to take into account both the high-voltage cathode and LMA. Ether-based electrolytes have been widely employed in LMBs for the fine compatibility between ethers and LMA. Nevertheless, the anodic limit of conventional ethers is below 4 V, which is suitable for low-voltage LMBs such as Li-LTO batteries, Li-LFP batteries, and Li-S batteries, yet stopped at high-voltage LMBs. High-concentration ehter electrolytes, localized high-concentration ether electrolytes, and fluorinated ether electrolytes are proposed to extend the anodic potential limitation of ether-based solvents [21,23–27]. However, in consideration of cost-effectiveness and environmental friendliness, large consumption of expensive Li salts and refractory fluorinated ethers is difficult to associate with practical LMBs. New organic solvents and electrolyte systems such as liquefied gas electrolytes, amide-based electrolytes, phosphate-based electrolytes, sulfonate-based electrolytes, and ionic-liquid-based electrolytes are developed to match high-voltage LMBs; however, they have temporarily stayed in the laboratory stage and not been commercialized due to various industrial application issues [28–32]. Carbonate-based electrolytes, closest to practicality among all types of solvents, have been employed in commercial LIBs for over 30 years. Their anodic limit is around 4.3 V due to their unique structures between the lone-pair electrons of ethereal oxygen and π*CO antibonding orbital, which is sufficient for most 4 V cathodes [26,33]. Nevertheless, commercial carbonate electrolytes, which generate stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) to passivate graphite anode, are incompatible with LMA and cause interfacial parasitic reactions. These continuous reactions deplete electrolyte components, consume active Li over time, produce gas, lead to the increasing resistance by thickening SEI, and ultimately drive Li to deposit in non-uniform, mossy, low-density, mechanically fragile structures during charging/discharging process, which limit lifetime and compromise the safety of LMBs [34–37]. Therefore, versatile strategies are developed to improve the compatibility between carbonates and LMA including high-concentration carbonate electrolytes, localized high-concentration carbonate electrolytes, fluorinated carbonate electrolytes, new Li salts, and additives [38–43]. Among these efforts, considering cost-effectiveness and environmental friendliness, the intentional finding and designing of the additives of interest to facilitate interfacial stability at the LMA and cathode provide the straightforward pathway to realize practical LMBs, because even ppm-level additive dosage can effectively optimize Li deposition morphology and efficiency under the premise of keeping commercial electrolyte systems unchanged. Additives can be divided into two types according to their functions: Li-deposition-regulation additives and film-forming additives [44]. Li-deposition-regulation additive is to adjust current distribution during depositing process to achieve uniform Li deposition by changing the reactivity of the LMA surface, which contains cesium ion (Cs+), rubidium ion (Rb+), and cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC) [45,46]. Film-forming additive can participate in the formation of SEI as a reactant to change the composition and structure of SEI and improve the physicochemical properties of SEI, which contains fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), difluoroethylene carbonate (DFEC), vinylene carbonate (VC), lithium difluorophosphate (LiPO2F2), boric acid (BA), lithium nitrate (LiNO3), lithium fluoride (LiF), tris(trimethylsilyl)borate (TMSB), trace water (H2O), heptafluorobutyric anhydride (HFA), lithium difluorophosphate (LiDFP), and magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3)2) [47–58]. Among these additives, LiNO3, an inorganic anionic film-forming additive, has been widely proved to construct a robust Li3N/Li2O/Li x NO y -rich SEI to effectively stabilize LMA by dissolving into ether-based electrolyte [59–62]. Unfortunately, numerous researches reveal that LiNO3 has poor solubility (∼800 ppm) in commercial carbonate electrolytes [63–68]. Therefore, the scientific introduction of LiNO3 additives into carbonates to stabilize LMAs in commercial carbonate electrolytes attracts extensive research interest for practical LMBs with 4-V-class cathode. 1.3 Scope of this review To date, there have been several superior reviews on liquid/solid electrolyte design, additives, interface regulation, SEI modification, LMA design, LMA current collectors, LiF additive, Li+-solvated structures in carbonates for LMBs, and even LiNO3 additive for Li batteries and Li-S batteries [20,34,44,69–79]. Unfortunately, a systematic review on regulating LiNO3 solvation chemistry in carbonates and how to introduce LiNO3 additive into carbonates is rarely reported, although the significance of low-cost LiNO3 coupling commercial carbonate electrolytes to stabilize LMA for practical LMBs is widely recognized. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , this review exclusively focuses on the grievances between LMA, LiNO3 and carbonates; a comprehensive analysis of stabilizing LMA mechanism of LiNO3, dissolution principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolyte, and LiNO3 introduction strategies is innovatively conducted for the first time; and it is expected that the direct introduction of LiNO3 into commercial carbonate electrolytes facilitates practical LMBs application with commercial 4-V-class cathodes. 2 Mechanisms of LiNO3 to stabilize LMA in carbonate electrolyte 2.1 Participating in Li+-solvated structure The anion of LiNO3 (NO3 −) owns the relatively high electron donating ability. As depicted in Fig. 2 (a), NO3 − exhibits an electron donor number (DN) value of 22 for Li+, which is lagrer than most carbonates such as ethylene carbonate (EC) (16), dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (17), propylene carbonate (PC) (15), and FEC (9) [63]. This means that the addition of NO3 − in the carbonate electrolyte can participate in Li+-solvated structure and squeeze out carbonate molecules in the Li+-solvated shell. This conclusion can be corroborated by Raman spectra and molecular dynamics (MD) simulation. The Raman spectra characterize the Li+ solvation structures of the pure FEC and dimethoxyethane (DME), 0.4 M LiPF6-DME, 0.5 M LiPF6 + 0.65 M LiNO3-DME, FEC-DME (FD), and FEC-DME/LiNO3 (FDN) electrolytes (Fig. 2b). The addition of LiNO3 slightly reduces the value of blueshift of PF6 − in FD electrolyte, resulting from the complete interaction of Li+ between NO3 − and PF6 −, which suggests that NO3 − enters into the solvation sheath of FDN electrolyte and then substitutes part of PF6 − anions [80]. Fig. 2(c) exhibits the snapshots of Li+ primary coordinated shells (within 2.75 Å), calculated radial distribution functions (g(r), solid lines) and coordination numbers (n(r)), dash lines) of the basic electrolyte (BE) and FEC/sulfolane (SL)/LiNO3-containing BE (BE-FEC-SL/LiNO3) [81]. It can be seen that additive-free BE, EC, and DMC molecules occupy the main parts in the first Li+-solvated shell; yet in the electrolyte with the addition of FEC-SL/LiNO3, the coordination numbers of EC and DMC slightly reduce and SL, NO3 −, and FEC appear in the primary Li+-solvated structure. Fig. 2(d) exhibits the binding energies of Li+ in typical solvation shells of BE-FEC-SL/LiNO3, NO3 −-involved solvation structures have lower binding energies, which means NO3 − is more inclined to coordinate with Li+ [81]. Fig. 2(e) exhibits the Li+-solvated structure without/with LiNO3 in FD electrolyte and FDN electrolyte, which intuitively demonstrats the participation of NO3 − in the Li+-solvated structure [80]. The interaction between Li+ and NO3 − greatly decreases the number of carbonate molecules surrounding Li+, which leads to the reduced reduction of solvent molecules during plating process. 2.2 Tailoring the electrical double layer (EDL) In the inner of a cell, Li+ exists in a solvated form in the liquid electrolyte. When a specific potential is employed in the battery system, the solvated Li+ is attracted to the LMA surface to form the EDL structure under the electric field. Noting that the formation of the EDL is earlier than that of SEI. Fig. 2(f) exhibits schematics of the EDL principle, and it demonstrates that only the species in direct coordination with Li+ can be vastly electrostatically brought to LMA surface [82]. That is, NO3 − owns large DN numbers to participate in the Li+-solvated structure, as mentioned in Section 2.1, thus can enter into the EDL. This conclusion is confirmed in Fig. 2(g), in the bulk electrolyte, FSI− appears in the diffusion layer, outer Helmholtz plane (OHP), and inner Helmholtz plane (IHP) [83]. While in the electrolyte with NO3 −, FSI− appears in the diffusion layer and OHP and NO3 − appears in the diffusion layer and IHP, this phenomenon means that the solvated NO3 − tailores the IHP, which plays a crucial role in the formation and chemical composition of SEI. The significant reduction in desolvation energy barrier (E a2) in IHP of NO3 −-containing electrolyte relative to bulk electrolyte is further revealed in Fig. 2(h), which means that NO3 −-containing IHP facilitates Li+ desolvation during plating [83]. Therefore, more efforts in tailoring the primary Li+-solvated structure and IHP are expected to explore the thermodynamics and dynamics of Li+ in the liquid electrolyte for LMBs, which play a foremost role in stabilizing LMA. 2.3 Manipulating inorganic-rich SEI LiNO3 is an excellent inorganic anionic film-forming additive, that is, its key role in stabilizing LMA is to form inorganic-rich SEI. According to Goodenough’s theory, the priority of reductive or oxidative decomposition of electrolyte components depends on the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular (HOMO) energy levels (Fig. 3 a) [84]. Precisely, the lower the LUMO, the easier to be reduced and the higher the HOMO, the more easily oxidized. In general, it is expected that the LUMO of solvents is higher than that of anode while HOMO lower than that of cathode to guarantee solvents not to be decomposed oxidatively and reductively, while Li salts and additives do it instead. Fig. 3(b) summarizes the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of LiNO3, common carbonates, and Li salts, it can be seen that the LUMO of LiNO3 (−1.53 eV) is similar to that of Li salts including LiPF6 (−2.15 eV), LiTFSI (−2.36 eV), LiBOB (−2.83 eV), and LiBF4 (−1.49 eV) except LiFSI (−0.39 eV), and lower than that of carbonates including EC (−0.60 eV), DMC (−0.37 eV), ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) (−0.26 eV), diethyl carbonate (DEC) (−0.27 eV), PC (−0.78 eV), and FEC (−0.80 eV). Noting that the formation of SEI strongly depends on the composition of the primary Li+-solvated structure and IHP, that is, it is LiNO3, not other Li salts, to first reductively decompose on the LMA surface to form SEI, which further protects solvents from being decomposed. As for LiNO3, its three O atoms have the same spin population (0.4) and its N atom owns the main negative charge (0.88), which implies that it accepts few electrons to deform and plenty of electrons to break the NO bonds (Fig. 3c) [59]. As a strong oxidant, it is easy enough to react with LMA, and the reduction reaction process can be described by Eqs. (2) and (3) [85]. (2) L i N O 3 + 2 L i → L i N O 2 + L i 2 O Δ H = - 406 k J m o l - 1 (3) L i N O 2 + 6 L i → L i 3 N + 2 L i 2 O Δ H = - 857 k J m o l - 1 From the reaction equations, we can see that eight electrons are needed from LMA to completely decompose LiNO3, and one LiNO3 decomposition can produce two Li2O and one Li3N. In-depth X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 3d), time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy (ToF-SIMS) (Fig. 3g), and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (Fig. 3h) can be employed to detect the reduction products. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of Li-Cu half cells can auxiliarily verify that the reduction potential of NO3 − is around 1.7 V vs. Li+/Li (Fig. 3f) [63,65,81]. It can be seen LiNO3-containing electrolyte forms smooth and thin inorganic-rich SEI, compared with the fragile and thick SEI formed by the LiNO3-free electrolyte (Fig. 3e) [63]. The inorganic-rich SEI is about 20 nm thickness (Fig. 3h) and mainly composed of Li2O, Li3N, and LiF. The Li2O and Li3N come from the decomposition of LiNO3 and LiF is from FEC in the LiNO3, FEC-containing electrolyte (Fig. 3i) [63,86,87]. Li3N provides high ionic conductivity (10−3 S cm−1) and low electronic conductivity (<10−12 S cm−1); Li2O and LiF exhibit high mechanical strength and interfacial energy, which effectively passivate the LMA and guarantee the fluky transport of Li+ during plating process [88,89]. 2.4 Regulating Li deposition morphology As mentioned above, NO3 − ions participate in the primary Li+-solvated structure, which in turn modulate the IHP in the EDL, resulting in a robust Li2O/Li3N/Li x NO y -rich SEI. Actually, the SEI unambiguously guides different morphologies of Li deposition [90]. In the growth process of Li dendrites, there is a critical thermodynamic radius r aq and a critical kinetic radius r k. (4) r a q = - 2 γ N E Ω z F η + Δ G f Ω (5) r k = - 2 γ N E Ω z F η Where γ NE represents the interfacial energy between Li and electrolyte, Ω is the molar volume of Li, z is the charge number, F is the Faraday constant, η is the overpotential, ΔG f is the conversion free energy per molar volume. The Li can nucleate only after overcoming r aq, and only when a nucleus is larger than r k, the nucleus grows into a crystal, otherwise, gradually disappears [91,92]. Furthermore, the Li-nucleus size is proportional to the reciprocal of the overpotential, and the Li-nucleus density is proportional to the third power of the overpotential [93]. Therefore, the LiNO3 regulating Li deposition mechanism can be drawn by combining the above conclusions. First, the reductive decomposition of LiNO3 generates an uniform Li2O/Li3N-rich SEI with fast Li-ion conduction, which reduces the Li nucleation overpotential. Second, the decreased overpotential leads to a big Li-nucleus size in low density, which means that most Li fails to nucleate owing to the lower radius than r aq. Third, the big-size Li nucleus laterally grow in a low-density status because these bits of Li nucleus exceeds the critical kinetic radius r k. Therefore, the addition of LiNO3 tends to promote dense Li deposition into spherical structures rather than needle-shaped dendrites (Fig. 4 a) [94]. Fig. 4(b–d) exhibits the dense, crack-free, and dendrite-free Li deposition morphology in LiNO3-containing chemical environment after several cycles compared to the counterpart [64,95]. Atomic force microscope (AFM) is employed to observe uniform and smooth Li deposition morphology of LiNO3-treated LMA as well as concave and convex expansion structure in LiNO3-free chemical environment (Fig. 4g) [96]. In-situ optical microscopy clearly shows the continuous growth of Li dendrites and dead Li with the increasing deposition time (Fig. 4e) or deposition capacity (Fig. 4f) in the absence of LiNO3, in stark contrast to the uniform and dense Li deposition with LiNO3 [64,81]. Stable inorganic-rich SEI and dense Li deposition caused by the reduction decomposition of LiNO3 lead to the reduced cell polarization and improved coulombic efficiency, thus the increased electrochemical performance of the cell. 3 Dissolution and insolubility principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes 3.1 Dissolution principle of LiNO3 additive The dissolution of ionic compounds highly relys on the Gutmann DN of the anion and acceptor number (AN) of the cation, which is related to their binding energy, the dielectric constant, and the DN value of the solvent [64]. In terms of LiNO3, its cation (Li+) has a small size and leads to a high local density of positive charge and the AN value of Li+ is 0.4 kcal mol−1. The anion (NO3 −) is a small anionic structure compared to the complex anionic groups of other Li salts (Fig. 5 a), thus endowing a relatively high negative charge and a high DN value (22 kcal mol−1). These properties of Li+ and NO3 − give LiNO3 a quite high binding energy (−4.63 eV) [64]. As for the dissolution of LiNO3, the strong binding energy of LiNO3 means its great coulombic force between Li+ and NO3 − in solid LiNO3 and limited solubility (∼800 ppm) in carbonate electrolyte. Fig. 5(b) exhibits the schematics of the equilibrium between dissociation and recombination of LiNO3 [97]. The maximum solubility of LiNO3 in the solvent is determined by the dynamic equilibrium between the dissociation (dissolution) of LiNO3 and the recombination (precipitation) of the solvated Li+-NO3 −. Consequently, to promote the dissolution of LiNO3, there are two routes. One is to facilitate the dissociation of LiNO3 by decreasing the dissociation energy, which requires the high dielectric constant and high DN value of solvent to increase LiNO3 ionization; the other is to prevent the Li+-NO3 − recombination by increasing the recombination energy, which requires that the carbonate co-solvent particpates in the Li+-solvated structure and owns functional groups to drive NO3 − away from this Li+-solvated aggregate [97]. 3.2 Insolubility of LiNO3 in single carbonate and commercial linear/cyclic carbonate electrolytes The great coulombic force between Li+ and NO3 − leads to the insolubility of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolyte. From the solvent perspective, the solubility of solvent to LiNO3 depends on the dielectric constant and DN value of the solvent. Fig. 6 (a) exhibits the molecular structures and physical parameters including dielectric constant, DN number, and solubility to LiNO3 of the common carbonates. It can be seen that cyclic carbonates exhibit fine solubility for LiNO3 (e.g. EC: 0.7 M and PC: 0.2 M) compared to linear carbonates (e.g. DMC/PC< 0.1 M) due to the apparently high dielectric constant (e.g. EC: 89.6, PC: 64.9 and DMC: 3.1, DEC: 2.8) under similar DN numbers. Obviously, this conclusion corrects the inherent perception that LiNO3 is completely insoluble in carbonates. However, the ionic conductivity of the LiNO3/EC electrolyte is lower under similar concentrations to other Li salts electrolyte, indicating the less mobility and dissociation of active Li+ in the electrolyte (Fig. 6b) [98]. Attenuated total reflectance fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) can be employed to confirm that the ionization of LiNO3 is promoted at low concentration; it cannot be fully dissociated at high concentration, but exists in the form of Li+/NO3 −/EC solvation sheath (Fig. 6c) [98]. The equilibrium dissociation reaction can be depicted as Eq. (6) [98]. (6) L i ( E C ) x + + N O 3 - ↔ L i + ( N O 3 - ) ( E C ) x - y + y E C Therefore, LiNO3-containing electrolytes solubilized by single cyclic carbonate are often difficult to be directly applied due to its low ionic conductivity. Commercial electrolytes tend to adopt linear carbonates to improve the viscosity/ionic conductivity and lower the melting point of cyclic carbonates, in the case of the latter high dielectric constant. However, even LiNO3 is employed as the sole Li source, DMC as EC co-solvent, the actual solubility of LiNO3 is lower than the theoretical value (Fig. 6d), implying that the addition of DMC affects the dissociation of LiNO3 [98]. Furthermore, even EC is employed as the single solvent, LiFSI and LiNO3 as the shared Li salts, the actual solubility of LiNO3 is also lower than the theoretical value due to LiFSI factor (Fig. 6e) [98]. Thus, it is not difficult to understand that LiNO3 is nearly insoluble in the terminated cyclic/linear mixed carbonate electrolytes (dual Li salts matching dual solvent system) (Fig. 6f) [81]. Therefore, the conclusion can be drawn that in the cyclic/linear carbonate electrolytes, Li salts with complex anions, such as LiFSI and LiPF6, can be effectively dissociated and dissolved in the mixed carbonates; yet, linear carbonate and Li salts occupy cyclic carbonates and prevent cyclic carbonates such as EC and PC to dissolve LiNO3, which creates an illusion that LiNO3 is nearly insoluble (Fig. 6g) [98]. 4 Strategies to introduce LiNO3 additive into carbonate electrolytes Practical LMBs are the development trend in the near/mid-term, carbonate electrolytes have long-term service for LIBs, and LiNO3 is a low-cost but highly effective additive in stabilizing LMA. Thus, coordinating the three points reasonably and developing LiNO3 modified carbonates for practical LMBs evolve into a concerned subject. The key of the subject lies in how to introduce LiNO3 due to the poor solubility of LiNO3 in the commercial cyclic/linear carbonates. Fig. 7 exhibits a brief timeline of the representative work to introduce LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes for practical LMBs, where three strategies have been developed to address this solubility issue from 2018 to the present. The most popular strategy is chemical solubilization, which overcomes the solubility limitation of LiNO3 in carbonates by manipulating the electrolyte solvation structure or designing suitable cations for NO3 − anion. Five routes including solvent carrier (Fig. 7p, r, s and y), co-solvent reservoir (Fig. 7b, j, k, o, t and z), ionic/group Lewis acid (Fig. 7c, f, g, h, n and w), inorganic/organic cation design (Fig. 7l, v and x), and single carbonate (Fig. 7u) have been developed to chemically solubilize LiNO3 [52,56,63–65,67,80,81,97–108]. Another strategy is physical release, which introduces LiNO3 into the interior of the cell through physical methods and slowly releases and replenishes LiNO3 as the limited LiNO3 is consumed for continuous SEI formation in the electrolyte, such as intrinsic/exogenous carrier (Fig. 7a, d, e and q) [94,109–111]. The last strategy is pre-reaction, which is to achieve the purpose of introducing LiNO3 by reacting LiNO3 with LMA in advance, such as pre-immersion/embedding reaction (Fig. 7i and m) [85,95]. 4.1 Chemical solubilization Chemical solubilization is to overcome the solubility limitation of LiNO3 in carbonates by chemical means, that is, increasing the conversion of insoluble solid LiNO3 in carbonates into soluble NO3 − and Li+. There are several feasible means can be implemented. The first route is to seek a polar solvent that dissolves LiNO3 massively as a carrier and add both into carbonates. The second route is to find carbonate co-solvent, which can just be used as a reservoir for LiNO3 in the mixed electrolyte. The third route is to seek Lewis acid to tune the solvation structure and liberate cyclic carbonates to solubilize LiNO3. The fourth route is to design large cations around NO3 − to weaken the huge coulombic force between NO3 − anion and cation to achieve solubilization. The fifth route is to solubilize LiNO3 with cyclic carbonates alone. Just as mentioned above, there are five strategies for the chemical solubilization of LiNO3 as follows. 4.1.1 Solvent carrier strategy Solvent carrier strategy is to hunt for an exogenous solvent as LiNO3 carrier to achieve LiNO3 solubilization in conventional carbonates. Generally, the carrier solvent dissolves high-concentration LiNO3 first, then the LiNO3-containing carrier as additive is added into carbonate electrolyte. On the one hand, the solvent carrier serves as LiNO3 reservoir in carbonate electrolyte; on the other hand, the LiNO3-containing carrier additive is miscible with carbonate to regulate the Li+-solvated structure together. Fig. 8 exhibits the exogenous solvent carrier strategies, where we can see that the strongly polar solvents such as SL, tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME), tetramethylurea (TMU), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), pyridine (Py), vinylene carbonate (VC), tetraglyme (TGM), and 1,4,8,11-tetramethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacylcotetradecane (tmCyclam) have been employed as carrier solvents to achieve LiNO3 solubilization. It can clearly see the insoluble precipitation of 0.1 M LiNO3 in the conventional carbonate electrolyte; while it dissolves into carbonate by SL carrier to form a homogeneous and transparent liquid in the electrolyte with carrier, which indicates that LiNO3 gets fully dissolved (Fig. 8a) [81]. The exogenous carrier such as Py owns high DN number to dissolve LiNO3 and cannot destroy the original carbonate structure (Fig. 8e) [112], yet it participates in the Li+-solvated structure together with LiNO3 (e.g. TMU/LiNO3 and DMSO/LiNO3) (Fig. 8c and d) to involve in the formation of SEI and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) [63,65]. Therefore, when choosing a carrier, a solvent with high LUMO and low HOMO energy level such as TGM is necessary to reduce the side reaction of SEI formation caused by carrier (Fig. 8g) [113]. The TEGDME/LiNO3-containing carbonate electrolytes formed stable SEI and dense Li deposition (Fig. 8b); the circular Li deposition morphology was formed in VC/LiNO3-containing carbonates instead of bulk dendrites in VC/LiNO3-free carbonates (Fig. 8f) [49,99]. And also, tmCyclam is found to promote LiNO3 dissociation and the SEI enhancer (tmCyclam/LiNO3) tunes SEI composition and formation of dense Li deposition (Fig. 8h) [114]. Although the significant improvement is available due to the successful introduction of LiNO3 by the carriers, these highly polar solvents participate in the Li+-solvated structure and tailore the EDL together with LiNO3, undoubtedly reacting seriously with LMA and 4-V-class cathode intrinsically, and thus weaken the effects of LiNO3. Therefore, while choosing a carrier solvent to stabilize LiNO3, the following parameters such as dielectric constant, DN value, and HOMO-LUMO energy level require a comprehensive investigation. Ideally, a solvent carrier owns two key features. The first feature is the high polarity, keeping high dielectric constant and DN value, to dissolve high-concentration of LiNO3, resulting in attaining miscibility with carbonates. The second feature is about the energy levels, where high LUMO and low HOMO energy level prohibit the side reactions both with cathode and LMA, or its decomposition products both with LMA and 4-V-class cathode, to realize desired CEI and SEI together with LiNO3. 4.1.2 Co-solvent reservoir strategy Co-solvent reservoir strategy is to seek a carbonate co-solvent as LiNO3 reservoir to achieve LiNO3 solubilization in carbonates. Generally, these co-solvents act as a solvent to dissolve Li salts together with carbonate and dissolve LiNO3 additive alone, which means they need occupy a high content in the electrolyte compared to exogenous carrier additives. Fig. 9 exhibits the co-solvent reservoir strategies, where we can see that the polar solvents such as ethylene glycol diacetate (EGD), triethyl phosphate (TEP), VC, γ-butyrolactone (GBL), TEGDME, dimethoxyethane (30 and 70 v% DME), and trimethyl phosphate (TMP) have been employed as carbonate co-solvents to solubilize LiNO3. Compared with EC and DMC to dissolve 0.2 M LiNO3 in the presence of precipitate, the combination of EC and EGD instead of DMC effectively solubilizes LiNO3 even to 0.6 M (Fig. 9a) [97]. The co-solvent reservoirs such as TEGDME (Fig. 9f) and DME (Fig. 9g and h) also participate in the Li+-solvated structure together with NO3 − and affect the effect of stabilizing LMA by NO3 − [80,100,102]. The LiNO3 successfully introduced by VC increases the overpotential of Li electrodeposition on the LMA, which suppresses the growth of Li crystal nucleus and the formation of Li dendrites (Fig. 9c) [115]. In addition, it is revealed that the addition of TMP/LiNO3 disperses Li growth direction to avoid dendritic Li caused by one-direction Li growth (Fig. 9e) [103]. Therefore, Li3N/Li x NO y -rich SEI by TEP/LiNO3 (Fig. 9b) and dense Li deposition morphology by GBL/LiNO3 (Fig. 9d) are achieved [101,116]. Noting that the co-solvent reservoirs, same as exogenous carriers, participate in the Li+-solvation structure, tailore the EDL together with NO3 −, and affect the effect of stabilizing LMA by NO3 −. Thus, co-solvent parameters such as dielectric constant, DN value, and HOMO-LUMO energy level also need enough attention. Compared with carrier additives, the incorporation of co-solvents reservoir has increased a lot, which requires their dielectric constant and DN value to be higher than that of carbonates while lower than that of carriers to facilitate LiNO3-dissolution; however, their LUMO needs strictly higher and HOMO needs strictly lower than carriers so as to avoid their unwanted decomposition reaction both with cathode and LMA. In addition, it is noted that most researches gathered in facilitating LiNO3 dissociation except EGD co-solvent, thus, the co-solvent strategy preventing Li+-NO3 − recombination is called for more attention here, which may creates new discoveries. 4.1.3 Lewis acid regulation strategy Lewis acid regulation strategy is to employ electron-deficient ions or groups to integrate large anionic (e.g. FSI− and PF6 −) and linear carbonates (e.g. DMC and DEC), which is just combined with cyclic carbonates (e.g. EC) in electrolyte, so that cyclic carbonates are free to dissolve LiNO3 (Fig. 10 a) [98]. These electron-deficient ions or groups are called as Lewis acid, which are divided into strong electron-deficient metal cations and weak electron-deficient groups. Fig. 10(b–h) exhibits the Lewis acid regulation strategies, where we can see that strong Lewis acid cations such as aluminum ion (Al3+), tin ion (Sn2+), Cu2+, indium ion (In3+), silver ion (Ag+), magnesium ion (Mg2+), zinc ion (Zn2+) and weak Lewis acid groups such as lithium tetrafluoroborate (LiBF4), tris(pentafluorophenyl)boron (TPFPB)/tris(pentafluorophenyl)phosphine (TPFPP) have been employed to solubilize LiNO3 in carbonate electrolyte. The phenomenon that the solubilization of LiNO3 in cyclic/linear carbonate (EC/DMC) but not in linear carbonate (DMC) is achieved by Lewis acid Al3+ confirms the above solubilization mechanism of Lewis acid (Fig. 10b) [98]. Trace of Lewis acid Cu2+ (0.2 wt% CuF2) solubilizes 1 wt% LiNO3 in the routine carbonate-based electrolyte (Fig. 10c) [52]. The ionic Lewis acids such as Sn2+ (Fig. 10d), In3+ (Fig. 10e), Mg2+, and Zn2+ (Fig. 10g) participate in the Li+-solvated structure, manipulate the component of SEI (e.g. Ag-Li alloy layer by Lewis acid Ag+ in Fig. 10f), and regulate Li deposition together with NO3 − [67,104,106,117]. Generally, the groups act as Lewis acid through an atom in the group such as electron-deficient boron (B) atom of LiBF4/TPFPB and electron-deficient phosphorus (P) atom of TPFPP. The group Lewis acids TPFPB and TPFPP effectively solubilize LiNO3 in carbonates due to electron-deficient B of TPFPB and P of TPFPP (Fig. 10h), they also participate in the solvated structure and affect SEI component and Li deposition (e.g. TPFPB/TPFPP in Fig. 10h and LiBF4 in Fig. 10i) [105,107]. Herein, it should be noted that the addition of Lewis acid, especially metal ionic Lewis acid, poses a concern of complex metal deposition on LMA and the separator, which induces uncontrollable risks of cell short circuit due to their involvement in SEI formation and Li deposition process. Therefore, in addition to the solubilizing effect of LiNO3, the rational selection and design of either ionic Lewis acids or group Lewis acids should consider facilitating the formation of robust SEI and dense Li deposition. 4.1.4 Intrinsic cation design strategy LiNO3 is considered as an anionic film-forming additive, that is, NO3 − plays a major role in stabilizing LMA. While, the insolubility of LiNO3 in carbonates is due to its great coulombic force between small Li+ and NO3 −. Therefore, intrinsic cation design strategy is to design complex cations or large cations to replace Li+ to weaken the interaction between cations and NO3 − anions, so as to achieve the introduction of NO3 − into carbonate electrolytes. Fig. 11 exhibits the intrinsic cation design strategies, where we can see that organic macrocation ((C4H9)4N+) and inorganic macrocation such as univalent macrocation (K+/Cs+/Rb+) and multivalent macrocation (Mg2+/Cu2+/In3+) have been employed to solubilize LiNO3. As the size of the organic cation gradually increases, the binding energy between cation and NO3 − progressively decreases from −4.63 eV (LiNO3) to −2.55 eV ((CH3)4N+NO3 −, TMAN), −2.31 eV (TEAN), and eventually −2.21 eV ((C4H9)4N+NO3 −, TBAN). Consequently, based on the weakened binding energy, it successfully introduce NO3 − to form Li3N-rich SEI (Fig. 11a) [64]. The inorganic univalent macrocation such as K+ is also employed to introduce NO3 −; in addition to forming the inorganic-rich SEI by the introduced NO3 −, the electrostatic shielding effect of K+ synergistically regulates the uniform Li+ flux to avoid the unrestricted growth of Li dendrites (Fig. 11b) [118]. Nevertheless, when the concentration of K+/Cs+/Rb+ nitrate reaches to 0.1 M, there is still some insoluble precipitation due to the insufficient solubilization caused by simply increasing the cation size, so the exogenous crown ether (18-crown-6) carrier is employed to synergistically introduce NO3 − (Fig. 11c) [119]. In addition to univalent macrocation, the multivalent macrocation such as Mg2+ is also employed to introduce NO3 − and it is confirmed that Mg2+ participates in the Li+-solvated structure, tailors the SEI, and regulates Li deposition together with NO3 − (Fig. 11d) [56]. Besides, the bivalent Cu2+ and trivalent In3+ without crystal water are unable to achieve a large amount of dissolution; while Cu(NO3)2 (Fig. 11e) and In(NO3)3 (Fig. 11f) with crystal water could successfully achieve solubilization due to the synergistic effect of crystal water and macrocation strategies, thus, participating in the Li+-solvated structure and regulating the spherical deposition morphology [108,120]. Of note, the crystal water in electrolyte is removed by molecular sieve after introducing nitrate. Here, it should be noted that potential side reactions induced by newly introduced cations should be taken into account when selecting macrocation to introduce NO3 −. An ideal design is that the cation not only helps to dissolve LiNO3, but also synergistically contributes to the improved electrochemical performances of the cell [108,121]. 4.1.5 Single cyclic carbonate strategy Single cyclic carbonate strategy is to employ cyclic carbonates with large dielectric constant and DN value to directly dissolve LiNO3 in single cyclic carbonates. As mentioned above, cyclic carbonates such as EC generally have high enough dielectric constant to dissolve LiNO3 alone, and commercial electrolytes reduce the viscosity and melting point of cyclic carbonates by adding linear carbonates to the former, yet resulting in low solubility of LiNO3 [98]. Therefore, cyclic carbonates can be used alone to dissolve LiNO3, however, corresponding modification strategies should be employed simultaneously to solve the issues caused by the absence of linear carbonates. 4.2 Physical release Physical release is to physically introduce LiNO3 into carbonates and release slowly to replenish with the continuous consumption of the limited LiNO3 in carbonates during SEI formation, thus, maintaining a constant amount of LiNO3 in the carbonate electrolytes. There are two routes surrounding the introduction of LiNO3 into intrinsic components of the cell or exogenous components for the physical release of LiNO3 as follows. 4.2.1 Intrinsic carrier strategy Intrinsic carrier strategy is to introduce LiNO3 into the inherent components of the cell such as separator and current collector, then the LiNO3-containing carriers slowly release LiNO3 into carbonate electrolyte with the continuous consumption of the dissolved limited LiNO3 in electrolyte during SEI formation. Fig. 12 exhibits the intrinsic carrier strategies, where we can see that separators such as polypropylene (PP), glass fiber (GF), gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) and current collector such as carbon-coated copper (Cu@C), gradient carbon nanotubes-polyaniline (CNF-PAN), branched polyethyleneimine-silver (BPEI-Ag), electron-insulating polymer film-Cu/carbon fiber mat (EI-CuCM) have been employed as carrier to introduce LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes. The PP separator carrier constructed by the biscuit-like PP/LiNO3/PP effectively loads LiNO3, and the LiNO3 particles enter the carbonate electrolyte in the form of Li+ and NO3 − to stabilize LMA despite its limited solubility (Fig. 12a) [110]. The strategy of soaking GF separator in LiNO3-containing solution and then drying can also introduce LiNO3 into the carbonate electrolyte, which well stabilizes the LMA together with FEC (Fig. 12b) [122]. The GPE intercalated with LiNO3 can also act as a LiNO3 separator carrier to generate a robust Li3N/Li2O/Li x NO y -rich SEI to effectively stabilize LMA (Fig. 12c) [123]. Interestingly, LiNO3 is also added into the current collector to contruct LiNO3-containing current collector carrier. The LiNO3-containing carbon-coated 3D Cu current collector host (Fig. 12d), LiNO3-containing conductivity gradients CNF-PAN current collector (Fig. 12e), LiNO3-containing BPEI-Ag current collector (Fig. 12f), and LiNO3-containing zero-volume-expansion Li-metal-composite-anode current collector (zeroVE-Li) (Fig. 12g) are developed as LiNO3 carrier to release LiNO3 into carbonates and stabilize the LMA [109,124–126]. Undoubtedly, the pre-storage of LiNO3 inevitably decreases the gravimetric specific energy of the cell due to the increase in total mass caused by the addition of LiNO3 and other appendages that cannot supply energy. In addition, it is necessary to pay attention to the influence of the introduction of a large amount of insoluble LiNO3 into the separator/current collector and its possible entry into the electrolyte on the transport of Li+ in the electrolyte and electron from current collector. 4.2.2 Exogenous carrier strategy Exogenous carrier strategy is to introduce exogenous carriers loaded with LiNO3 into the cell system, then conduct sustained release into electrolyte from the LiNO3-containing carrier during the consumption for SEI formation. Fig. 13 exhibits the exogenous carrier strategies, where we can see that polystyrene-block-poly (2-vinyl pyridine) (S2VP) micelle, poly-(vinylidene fluorideco-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP), covalent organic framework (COF), polymeric vinylene carbonate (PVC), stainless steel mesh (SSM), and metal organic framework (MOF) have been employed as carrier to introduce LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes. LiNO3-containing S2VP micelle (Fig. 13a)/PVDF-HFP (Fig. 13b)/COF (Fig. 13c)/PVC (Fig. 13d)/SSM (Fig. 13e) film covering on the surface of LMA regulates uniform Li+ flux and generates N-rich inorganic SEI [94,111,127–129]. In addition, compared to other films with crystalline LiNO3, PVC film with dissociated LiNO3 in a state of low activation energy benefits the fast LiNO3-release into carbonates. However, it should be pointed out that a LiNO3-loaded film is bound to increase the overall weight of the cell leading to reduce the gravimetric specific energy, and the existence of the film also blocks the Li+ transport and increases the internal polarization of the cell during charging/discharging. Therefore, a film that is both light and thin enough, does not hinder the solvated Li+ transport, and is loaded with a suitable amount of LiNO3 is desired. LiNO3 is also encapsulated in the MOF-808 and added into the electrolyte together, which effectively generates a stable Li3N-rich SEI (Fig. 13f) [130]. Nevertheless, it should be considered that adding such small amounts of LiNO3-loaded MOF to a coin cell can be unmanageable, that is, it may not be well quantified at very small doses. 4.3 Pre-reaction Pre-reaction is to pretreat the surface or bulk of LMA with LiNO3 solution or LiNO3 powders to form a stable SEI before assemblying the cell, so as to stabilize LMA in carbonate electrolyte during working process. There are two routes surrounding the surface or bulk pretreatment of LMA as follows. 4.3.1 Pre-immersion reaction strategy Pre-immersion reaction strategy is to pre-immerse LMA in a nitrate-containing solution to react and form a stable Li3N-rich SEI on the surface of LMA before the cell assembly. Fig. 14 (a–c) exhibits the pre-immersion reaction strategies, where we can see that PCl5-LiNO3 (PN)-containing DME solution, LiNO3-containing diethylene glycol dimethyl ether (DEGDME) solution, and Mn(NO3)2-containing solution have been employed to immerse LMA and react with LMA. The LMA forms a robust Li3N/Li3PO4/LiCl-rich SEI in PN-containing DME solution, which achieve the combination of the fast Li-ion conductor (Li3N) and strong mechanical stability (Li3PO4), compared to the SEI formed in PCl5 or LiNO3-containing DME solution alone (Fig. 14a) [95]. The SEI formed in LiNO3-containing DEGDME solution enables LMA a dense and uniform morphology after cycling for 10 cycles in carbonate electrolyte, compared to the uneven shape of bare LMA (Fig. 14b) [96]. In addition, LMA is also pre-immersed in Mn(NO3)2-containing carbonate solution, which shows the reactive discoloration and results in stable Li deposition with a prolonged lifespan compared to the untreated LMA (Fig. 14c) [131]. Herein, two points should be noted. One is the selection of the solvent and auxiliary solute for the LMA pre-immersion, which plays a key role in the formation of SEI. The solvent in good compatibility with metallic Li and the solute that reductively generates ideal SEI components should be considered emphatically. The other is that before the cell is assembled using carbonates, the residue from the previous solution and reaction needs to be washed off to avoid unnecessary side reactions. Besides, it cannot get repaired once the SEI formed by the pretreatment is damaged during working, which will lead to rapid failure of the cell. 4.3.2 Pre-embedding reaction strategy Pre-embedding reaction strategy is to pre-intercalate nitrates powders into the metallic Li to react stably and conduct Li protection task during working. A repeated mechanical rolling/folding method is employed to pre-intercalate LiNO3 powders into the metallic Li so that metallic Li and LiNO3 powders react uniformly and fully to generate Li3N/LiN x O y /Li2O, thus, achieving bulk-to-surface Li protection in carbonate electrolytes (Fig. 14d) [85]. In addition to forming a stable Li3N-rich SEI, K+ introduced by KNO3 can form an electrostatic shield to regulate the Li+ deposition behavior (Fig. 14e) [132]. Noting that the proportion of LiNO3/KNO3 in the LMA as well as the physical uniformity and reactive uniformity of LiNO3/KNO3 in the LMA need to be strictly controlled, because these factors have a significant impact on the deposition effect of Li on the LMA. In conclusion, versatile introduction strategies for LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes mainly adopt the following routes: (1) the polar solvents provide the soluble reservoir for LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes (solvent carrier and co-solvent reservoir); (2) the electron-deficient ions or groups regulate the solubility environment of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes (Lewis acid regulation); (3) organic and inorganic macrocations decrease the impeditive coulombic force between Li+ and NO3 − (intrinsic cation design); (4) single cyclic carbonates provide the direct solubility environment of LiNO3; (5) physical release strategies provide a embedding medium for LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes (intrinsic and exogenous carrier); (6) pre-reaction strategies directly provide the desired SEI by LiNO3 pre-reaction with LMA (pre-immersion and pre-embedding reaction). A summary of these strategies to introduce LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes for practical LMBs is exhibited in Table S1 (Supporting Information). The radar plots of each strategy based on six dimensions of introduction ability, practicality, safety, side reaction, energy density, and overpotential are summarized in Fig. 15 for a clear comparison. Notwithstanding the present promising results, these strategies still have great room to improve in order to meet the practical requirements. The severe side reactions with LMA/cathode resulting from polar solvent carrier/reservoir, the complex metal depositions by Lewis acid, and the increased polarization and the reduced gravimetric specific energy by the addition of exogenous carrier are of particular concern and should be properly resolved. 5 Summaries and outlooks Practical LMBs are promising energy storage devices, but are prone to form unstable SEI and generate continuous dendrites and dead Li in carbonate-based electrolytes. LiNO3, an excellent inorganic anionic film-forming additive, widely proves effective to construct a robust Li3N/Li2O/Li x NO y -rich SEI to effectively stabilize LMA, yet has a limited solubility in the commercial carbonate electrolytes. Therefore, generating inorganic-rich SEI and dendrite-free LMA via introducing LiNO3 into carbonate electrolyte is of feasible and cost-effective concern for practical LMBs. This review highlights the grievances between LMA, LiNO3 and carbonates, and an in-depth investigation of the LMA stabilizing mechanism originated from LiNO3 has been clarified, including participating in Li+-solvated structure, tailoring the EDL, manipulating inorganic-rich SEI, and regulating Li deposition morphology. Moreover, the dissolution principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes is also demonstrated, such as solubility principle as well as insoluble cause in single carbonates and commercial cyclic/linear mixed carbonate electrolytes. Finally, the introduction strategies of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes have also been emphasized, such as chemical solubilization, physical release, and pre-reaction. To the best of our knowledge, although significant advances have been made in LiNO3 stabilizing LMA in commercial carbonates, more efforts need to be directed to achieve new breakthrough and enhanced efficiency so as to overcome the challenges in front of the practical application. (1) Other strategies or additives can be employed to synergistically stabilize the LMA with LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes. LiNO3 reductively decomposes on the surface of LMA to form Li3N-rich SEI, which is a fast-ion conductor for Li+, yet suffers from insufficient mechanical strength to completely inhibit the puncture by dendrite growth. Thus, additives that participate in the Li+-solvated structure and their reduction products with low-electron conductivity, strong Young's modulus, and high interfacial energy such as LiF can be introduced to form a more desirable SEI together with Li3N. Moreover, it is well known that LiNO3 is a sacrificial additive, with a maxium dosage of ∼5 wt%, which depletes quite readily as the SEI turns consumptive. Therefore, a more dense and stable SEI helps to suppress the consumption of LiNO3. (2) The addition of highly polar carriers, reservoirs, and metal ions in the chemical solubilization strategy leads to complex chemical reactions or metal deposition, which needs to be properly addressed so as to avoid the side effects that weaken the effect of stabilizing LMA by the introduced LiNO3. The best results are both the successful introduction of NO3 − by these additions and the fact that they favor the desired SEI formation or dense Li deposition. (3) In the 4-V-class LMBs, there are still some issues such as the dissolution of transition metal cations and the gas generation of the electrolyte catalytically decomposed by active oxygen radicals from the layered cathodes. Thus, in addition to introducing LiNO3, smart electrolyte design also needs to address these issues to stabilize the LMA in carbonate electrolytes. (4) Safety hazards such as flammability and explosion are of great significance in promoting liquid LMBs to solid LMBs. Thus, designing non-flammable electrolyte combined with LiNO3 is possible solution towards the stabilized LMA for safe LMBs. Furthermore, in addition to insolubility issue, LiNO3 itself is a strong oxidant and noxious combustion supporting agent, which is a notable source of potential unsafety. Therefore, the development of safer and soluble NO3 −-containing reagent (such as isosorbide dinitrate) to form Li3N-rich SEI may be a finer alternative [133]. (5) As the ex-situ characterizations fail to provide the real-time information on the Li+-solvated structure, gas generation, SEI/CEI evolution, and Li deposition behavior, the advances in the field of non-destructive and in-situ SEI characterizations are highly demanded to get in-depth understanding about how LiNO3-incorporation is improving the performance of practical LMBs. In addition, the purpose of introducing LiNO3 into carbonates is of great importance for the practical LMBs, thus, the pouch cell and standard parametric designs such as low negative/positive ratio and electrolyte/cathode ratio are needed in order to align academic research to industrial production. Kun Wang received his B.S. degree in 2017 and M.S. degree in 2020 at Central South University. He is now pursuing his Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Chengdu Liang and Prof. Min Ling at Zhejiang University. His research interest focuses on electrolyte and interface for lithium-metal batteries. Jun Chen received his Ph.D. degree in 2021 at Beijing Normal University, China. Currently, he is working as a full faculty member at Institute of Zhejiang University-Quzhou. His research interest focuses on electrodes (modified by ion beam technology), binders and electrolytes for energy storage applications including lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and lithium-metal batteries. Min Ling received his Ph.D. degree in 2015 at Griffith University, Australia. Afterward, he was a postdoctoral fellow at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab until 2017. Currently, he is working as a full faculty member at Zhejiang University. His research interest focuses on binders and electrolytes for energy storage applications including lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium-metal batteries, and lithium-sulfur batteries. Chengdu Liang received his Ph.D. in 2005 in Materials Chemistry and Analytical Chemistry at the University of Tennessee Knoxville, America. After a short period of postdoctoral research at the Chemical Science Division of Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), he started his career as a staff scientist at the Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences of ORNL in 2006. Currently, he is working as a full faculty member at Zhejiang University. His research interest focuses on the synthesis of advanced materials for energy storage applications including lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, sodium-ion batteries, fuel cells, and heterogeneous catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Li-metal batteries (LMBs) regain research prominence owing to the ever-increasing high-energy requirements. Commercially available carbonate electrolytes exhibit unfavourable parasitic reactions with Li-metal anode (LMA), leading to the formation of unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and the breed of Li dendrites/dead Li. Significantly, lithium nitrate (LiNO3), an excellent film-forming additive, proves crucial to construct a robust Li3N/Li2O/Li x NO y -rich SEI after combining with ether-based electrolytes. Thus, the given challenge leads to natural ideas which suggest the incorporation of LiNO3 into commercial carbonate for practical LMBs. Regrettably, LiNO3 demonstrates limited solubility (∼800 ppm) in commercial carbonate electrolytes. Thence, developing stable SEI and dendrite-free LMA with the incorporation of LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes is an efficacious strategy to realize robust LMBs via a scalable and cost-effective route. Therefore, this review unravels the grievances between LMA, LiNO3 and carbonate electrolytes, and enables a comprehensive analysis of LMA stabilizing mechanism with LiNO3, dissolution principle of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes, and LiNO3 introduction strategies. This review converges attention on a point that the LiNO3-introduction into commercial carbonate electrolytes is an imperious choice to realize practical LMBs with commercial 4 V layered cathode.

coredata.dc:title: Lithium nitrate regulated carbonate electrolytes for practical Li-metal batteries: Mechanisms, principles and strategies
